unnormalised: Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Quality Control Under Scrutiny
normalised: Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Quality Control Under Scrutiny

unnormalised: New Delhi, India – Concerns are rising regarding quality control processes within several key manufacturing sectors, prompting calls for stricter adherence to international standards. A recent report highlighted inconsistencies in the production of components destined for the automotive and electronics industries, potentially impacting the downstream supply chain.
normalised: New Delhi, India – Concerns are rising regarding quality control processes within several key manufacturing sectors, prompting calls for stricter adherence to international standards. A recent report highlighted inconsistencies in the production of components destined for the automotive and electronics industries, potentially impacting the downstream supply chain.

unnormalised: The National Institute of Quality Assurance (NIQA) has announced a series of workshops scheduled for October 2024 aimed at upskilling personnel and introducing advanced quality control methodologies. These initiatives come after feedback from the Automotive Component Manufacturers Association of India (ACMA) suggesting gaps in testing and validation.
normalised: The National Institute of Quality Assurance (N I Q A) has announced a series of workshops scheduled for October two thousand and twenty four aimed at upskilling personnel and introducing advanced quality control methodologies. These initiatives come after feedback from the Automotive Component Manufacturers Association of India (A C M A) suggesting gaps in testing and validation.

unnormalised: Experts point to the need for a "3 Idiots"-esque approach, emphasizing innovation and critical thinking in quality assurance, rather than rote adherence to checklists. Specific areas of concern include the precision machining of engine parts and the reliability testing of electronic circuits. Failure rates have reportedly increased by 7% in certain product lines, potentially costing manufacturers crores of Rupees in recalls and reputational damage. NIQA aims to reduce these failures by 15% by the end of next year.
